The autopsy report of Varanasi native and third-year student indicated death by poison, police said, reports S Boral.The student had borrowed money from her classmates, professors, and her mother to invest.Police sources said accused Faiz Ali, Mohammed Kaif, Jahid Hossain, and Kamran were part of a gang operating on Telegram app. Birbhum SP Rajnarayan Mukherjee said: "Our probes have indicated that this (the death) was due to the huge financial burden on the victim for the unpaid loans to her peers and family." Acting on a complaint lodged by Anamika's mother, police registered an abetment to suicide FIR. "My daughter was forced to die. There was mounting pressure on her," the mother alleged.
Article Summary: Police sources said accused Faiz Ali, Mohammed Kaif, Jahid Hossain, and Kamran were part of a gang operating on Telegram app. Anamika had borrowed money from her classmates, professors, and her mother to invest.

Article Title: 60 new medical colleges get govt approval
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Centre has approved 60 new medical colleges across the country. With this, the number of medical colleges has increased from 706 in 2023-24 to 766 so far in 2024-25. In the past decade, there has been a 98% increase in the number of medical colleges - from 387 in 2013-14 to 766 (govt: 423, private: 343) in 2024-25, according to health ministry."The number of MBBS seats in India has increased 6%, from 1,08,940 in 2023-24 to 1,15,812 in 2024-25," said a senior official.She said there has been a 6% increase in PG medical seats , from 69,024 in 2023-24 to 73,111 in 2024-25. "During the last 10 years, the number of PG seats increased by 39,460 (i.e. 127%) from 2013-14 (31,185 seats) to 2024-25 (73,111 seats)," the official said.
Article Summary: The number of medical colleges has increased from 706 in 2023-24 to 766 so far in 2024-25. In the past decade, there has been a 98% increase in the number ofmedical colleges. The number of MBBS seats in India has increased 6%, according to health ministry.

Article Title: Chakmas to PM: Help stop attacks on ethnic minorities in Bangladesh
Article Text: AIZAWL: Thirteen Chakma organisations in Mizoram, including political parties, sent a memorandum to PM Narendra Modi Sunday, urging his intervention to halt attacks on indigenous ethnic minorities in Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh . Chakmas share ties of ethnicity and kinship with such groups in the neighbouring country.The organisations alleged at least nine people were killed, many wounded and hundreds left homeless following attacks by illegal settlers backed by army personnel on Sept 19.According to the memorandum, the attacks came in the wake of Bangladesh interim govt's decision to grant magisterial and policing powers to the army.The attacks were reportedly a response to a peaceful "March for Identity" held on Sept 18 in CHT, during which 40,000 indigenous people called for constitutional recognition of their rights and full implementation of a 1997 peace accord. The memorandum cited demographic changes due to settlement of five lakh illegal Muslims between 1979 and 1983, which left indigenous population marginalised. It drew attention to historical injustices suffered by non-Muslim minorities in the region since Partition.
Article Summary: Thirteen Chakma organisations in Mizoram, including political parties, sent a memorandum to PM Narendra Modi Sunday. They urged his intervention to halt attacks on indigenous ethnic minorities in Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh. Chakmas share ties of ethnicity and kinship with such groups.

Article Title: Anura Kumara Dissanayake: PM Modi congratulates Anura Kumara Dissanayake on winning Sri Lanka's Presidential elections
Article Text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi extended his heartfelt congratulations to Sri Lanka ’s President-elect Anura Kumara Dissanayake on his victory in the Sri Lankan Presidential election on Sunday.In a message posted on social media platform X, PM Modi expressed his optimism for stronger ties between the two nations, highlighting Sri Lanka’s key role in India’s foreign policy."Congratulations, Anura Kumara Dissanayake, on your victory in the Sri Lankan Presidential elections . Sri Lanka holds a special place in India's Neighbourhood First Policy and Vision SAGAR. I look forward to working closely with you to further strengthen our multifaceted cooperation for the benefit of our people and the entire region," he said.In his message, PM Modi highlighted Sri Lanka’s importance in India's ‘Neighbourhood First Policy’ and Vision SAGAR (Security and Growth for All in the Region), which focuses on cooperative maritime measures.India’s High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Santosh Jha, also met with Dissanayake to offer his congratulations."HC Santosh Jha called on Sri Lanka President-elect Anura Kumara Dissanayake. Conveyed greetings from India's leadership and congratulated him on winning the people's mandate. India, as Sri Lanka's civilisational twin, is committed to further deepen ties for the prosperity of the people of our two countries," the Indian High Commission stated in an X post.Dissanayake, 55, is the leader of the leftist Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) party, was declared the winner in the country’s first-ever presidential election run-off.He defeated his rival Sajith Premadasa, securing his position as Sri Lanka’s 9th Executive President, according to the Election Commission.The historic run-off saw incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe finish third, resulting in his elimination after the first round of voting.This marked Wickremesinghe's third unsuccessful attempt at the presidency, following prior bids in 1999 and 2005.
Article Summary: Sri Lanka's President-elect Anura Kumara Dissanayake was declared the winner in the country’s first-ever presidential election run-off on Sunday. PM Modi expressed his optimism for stronger ties between the two nations, highlighting Sri Lanka's key role in India's foreign policy.

Article Title: Odisha orders judicial probe into 'torture' of Army officer, fiancée
Article Text: BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Mohan Majhi late on Sunday night ordered a judicial probe into the September 15 Bharatpur police station incident in which an Army officer and his fiancée were allegedly tortured, and the woman was allegedly subjected to sexual assault.Besides, the govt requested the Orissa high court to directly monitor the ongoing Crime Branch investigation into the crime.A govt statement said the judicial commission of inquiry under the chairmanship of Justice Chitta Ranjan Das will inquire into the incident. The commission has been requested to submit a report within 60 days.The govt statement said the CM has laid maximum emphasis on the rule of law. “The state government respects the Indian Army. The state government is fully concerned about the dignity, safety and rights of women. The concerned police officers have been suspended and a case has also been registered against them. Action has also been taken against the youth involved in the incident. The state government is committed to take strict action against all persons or officials who are deviating under the law,” the govt said.Earlier, on the instructions of CM, the Army officer and his female friend held a meeting with deputy chief ministers Kanak Vardhan Singhdeo and Pravati Parida, revenue and disaster management minister Suresh Pujari and law minister Prithviraj Harichandan at the State Guest House. The woman's father and other senior serving army officers were also present.
Article Summary: Chief minister Mohan Majhi has ordered a judicial probe into the September 15 Bharatpur police station incident. An Army officer and his fiancée were allegedly tortured, and the woman was allegedly subjected to sexual assault. The concerned police officers have been suspended and a case has also been registered against them.

Article Title: Article 370 won’t be revived, come what may: Rajnath Singh
Article Text: JAMMU: BJP will not allow restoration of Article 370 “come what may”, defence minister Rajnath Singh declared Sunday and accused National Conference (NC), Congress and People’s Democratic Party (PDP) of trying to mislead voters by saying they would ensure the junked provision’s return.“They are making a lot of noise over Article 370. How will you restore it? Only a government at the Centre has the power to do so,” Rajnath told a poll rally in Jammu’s Poonch in support of BJP candidate Choudhary Abdul Gani.Referring to a recent statement of Pakistan defence minister Khawaja Asif calling for the restoration of J&K’s special status, Rajnath alleged the NC-Congress alliance were “on the same page” as Islamabad on the issue.
Article Summary: Rajnath Singh accuses National Conference (NC), Congress and People’s Democratic Party (PDP) of trying to mislead voters. “They are making a lot of noise over Article 370. How will you restore it? Only a government at the Centre has the power to do so,” Rajnath said.

Article Title: BJP govt in J&K essential for peace, prosperity: Amit Shah
Article Text: Srinagar/Jammu: Union home minister Amit Shah emphasised Sunday the need for a BJP govt in J&K to ensure peace, prosperity, and development while accusing previous administrations led by PDP, National Conference (NC), and Congress of depriving the people of their rights and contributing to the decades-long unrest in the region.Speaking at an election rally in Nowshera of Rajouri district in Jammu division, Shah said only a BJP govt in J&K can give a befitting reply to terrorism and teach a lesson to Pakistan for fomenting trouble in the region.Shah dismissed any possibility of engaging in talks with Pakistan until terrorism is fully eradicated. "We will not talk to Pakistan until terrorism is gone. These political parties want to reopen LOC trade and bring terrorism back into J&K, but we will never allow that."Shah also assured that BJP govt under PM Narendra Modi has ensured safety along the border. “Now there is no need for bunkers in the border areas. If bullets come, we will respond with shells. The Indian flag will now always fly high in Kashmir.”Highlighting the impact of the abrogation of Article 370 in 2019, Shah said it marked a new era of peace, development, and the end of terrorism. “I know how much the people here suffered, and how PDP, NC, and Congress took your rights away. But after the abrogation of Article 370, tell me, was it good or bad? (NC president) Farooq Abdullah says he will bring it back, but I can assure you, no one will ever get it back.”In a sharp rebuke to Abdullah, Shah accused him of neglecting Kashmir during its darkest times. “For 30 years, terrorism thrived here, curfews were imposed, and 40,000 people were killed. Farooq Sahib was in London while Kashmir burned.”Shah criticised opposition promises, accusing them of misleading the public. “NC is promising to release terrorists and stone-throwers from jails for their gains, but PM Modi will crush terrorism in J&K. We will never free those who harmed our people.”He outlined BJP’s development vision for J&K, promising to improve connectivity and unveil plans for an international airport, a metro rail system in Jammu, and five lakh govt jobs for youth. “We will expose those who brought terrorism to J&K, those who ate biryani with terrorists. The then home minister couldn’t even visit Kashmir, but now, under PM Modi, anyone can walk freely through Lal Chowk (in Srinagar), even late at night. Tourism and cinemas have returned to J&K,” he said, highlighting the return of normality in the region.The Union minister also affirmed that no one will be allowed to touch reservations for Paharis, Gujjars, Dalits, and other backward classes, stressing that BJP will protect the rights of the deprived sections.Shah rejected NC’s manifesto promise of renaming Shankaracharya Hill as Takht-e-Suleiman and Hari Parbat as Koh-e-Maran, saying: “No one has the courage to change the name of Shankaracharya mountain...this will be known by the name of Shankaracharyaji for ages.”He underscored the successful completion of the first phase of polling on Sept 18 and expressed confidence in a BJP victory. “No NC-Congress govt will be formed. I can tell you this. On Sept 25 (second phase), vote for the candidate who will work for you, vote for our BJP candidate, and we will ensure your welfare.”
Article Summary: Union home minister Amit Shah emphasised the need for a BJP govt in J&K to ensure peace, prosperity, and development. He accused previous administrations led by PDP, National Conference (NC), and Congress of depriving the people of their rights and contributing to decades-long unrest in the region.

Article Title: Army nabs, detains PoK intruder in Poonch
Article Text: JAMMU: Army detained a 35-year-old Pakistan-occupied Kashmir PoK ) national nabbed near a forward post along Line of Control in Jammu & Kashmir’s Poonch district on Sunday for sneaking into India."Hassam Shahzad, from PoK’s Tatrinote village along LoC, is being questioned. A Pakistani national ID card, two mobile SIM cards, a key, and ₹1,800 in Pakistani currency were recovered from him,” a source said.
Article Summary: Hassam Shahzad, from PoK’s Tatrinote village along LoC, is being questioned. A Pakistani national ID card, two mobile SIM cards, a key, and ₹1,800 in Pakistani currency were recovered from him.

Article Title: Die is cast: Hindu refugee families from Pakistan to vote first time since 1947
Article Text: SRINAGAR: For the first time since their ancestors migrated from Pakistan to J&K during the 1947 Partition, over 5,000 Hindu families will vote in the ongoing assembly elections .Forced to live in 39 squalid camps near Jammu for over seven decades because Article 370 on J&K’s special status denied them land and other rights, these refugees are looking forward to the Oct 1 polls as a watershed moment.The right to exercise their franchise follows Article 370’s abrogation in Aug 2019, a move which cleared the way for granting these refugees permanent resident status after decades of political marginalisation.To add to their political heft, two seats have been reserved for these immigrants in the assembly. The Centre will nominate the two members.“For us, voting day will be a festival,” said Labhu Ram, president of West Pakistan Refugee Action Committee, adding the families will celebrate the ballot with special dishes like puri-halwa and laddus to express excitement and gratitude for this long-awaited opportunity.The ancestors of the refugees, numbering around 5,700 and mostly from Scheduled Castes (SCs), have lived so far without many of the rights and privileges enjoyed by residents. “The abrogation brought about a seismic shift in our political status, finally allowing us full participation in the electoral process. Till now, we were living as second-class citizens. This basic democratic right was snatched away from us by those who today claim to safeguard democratic institutions,” said Des Raj, a camp resident, alluding possibly to J&K-based parties.Some of the refugees were forced to leave areas of Kashmir occupied by Pakistan in 1947, while others came from areas of Sialkot, bordering Jammu. They were provided land in Jammu in 1960s but Article 370 --- which barred outsiders from owning land in J&K -- meant no ownership rights. This prevented them from getting benefits of govt housing schemes or access to bank loans. These refugee families were treated as “non-state subjects” as they not were not residents of the then princely state of J&K during the 1947 Partition.Ahead of a Supreme Court-stipulated Sept 30 deadline for holding the assembly polls, J&K administration on Aug 2 this year granted the refugees proprietary rights to the “state land” on which their ancestors were settled by the then govt decades ago.The Hindu refugees ’ livelihood and survival problems date back to the 1974 Partition, based on the nation theory, which led to large-scale cross-border migration and mayhem. In those tumultuous days, many Hindu families fled villages in Pakistan’s Sialkot and came to neighbouring Jammu’s Kathua and RS Pura areas. While some stayed back in Jammu, many others left and settled in Punjab, Delhi and other states of India.The main reason for the influx into Jammu was connectivity: Sialkot was then linked to Jammu by rail and road. Such people also shared cultural and economic affinity with Dogras of Jammu. According to some historians, many of the refugees had relatives in border villages of Jammu, leading them to be welcomed in the initial years of the crisis.
Article Summary: For the first time since their ancestors migrated from Pakistan to J&K during the 1947 Partition, over 5,000 Hindu families will vote in the ongoing assembly elections. The right to exercise their franchise follows Article 370’s abrogation in Aug 2019, a move which cleared the way for granting these refugees permanent resident status.

Article Title: Gunfight resumes in Kishtwar, J&K
Article Text: JAMMU: A gunfight broke out between security forces and terrorists near Danna Dhar forest of Chatroo in the upper reaches of Kishtwar district in Jammu division of J&K Sunday evening, following a brief exchange of fire that took place in the same area about 23 hours earlier.A police spokesman said firing resumed after security forces spotted the terrorists hiding in the deep forest.No casualty was reported so far. On Saturday, the forces had engaged with a group of at least two-three suspected Pakistani terrorists in Chatroo.The area has seen heightened security ops in recent days. On Sept 13, two soldiers were killed and as many wounded in a gunfight in Pingnal Dugadda forest near Naidgham village of Chatroo.
Article Summary: A gunfight broke out between security forces and terrorists near Danna Dhar forest of Chatroo in the upper reaches of Kishtwar district in Jammu division of J&K Sunday evening. On Saturday, the forces had engaged with a group of at least two-three suspected Pakistani terrorists in Chatroo.

Article Title: 'Visvesvaraya made technocracy fashionable'
Article Text:
Sharmila Ganesan Ram



Among the most famous Indian engineers of the 20th century was the legendary Mokshagundam Visvesvaraya. What factors prompted you to pick him as the subject of your new biography 'Engineering a Nation'?



To explore Visvesvaraya's life, the book argues, is to understand the emergence of the Indian nation itself...



The 500-odd-page biography is suffixed by 200 pages of citations. Walk us through the research process.



A museum, a college, a terminal, a memorial trophy-- Visvesvaraya's name lives on in many forms in Karnataka. Is his legacy well-known outside the state? Do you think he received his due?



What role did Bombay play in his trajectory?



While Gandhi was against the idea of industrialisation, Visvesvaraya swore by it as a tool for nation-building. Did the two men see eye-to-eye?



Much like your subject, you too chose to go abroad. After studying electrical engineering, you pursued postgraduate work in the history of science, medicine and technology at Oxford University (MSc) and Imperial College London (PhD). What prompted this leap from science to history/from the future to the past of the future, if you will?



The Indian Science Congress--a 1914-born annual forum in which a lot of attendees in recent years have made controversial claims about India's achievements in the history of science spanning the existence of stem cell technology to fleets of aircraft in ancient India and Sri Lanka--did not happen this year. What does this (both the event and its cancellation) say about India's relationship with science and history? Also, did you miss it?



If he were alive, what would Visvesvaraya have to say about AI, UID, UPI and present-day India?

Add reaction



ReplyForward

Add reaction



If he were alive, legendary 20th-century civil engineer Mokshagundam Visvesvaraya would likely be excited about AI , guesses historian Aparajith Ramnath whose book ' Engineering A Nation ' delves into the scientist's century-wide life and legacy. Apart from being an early proponent of economic planning and large-scale industrialisation, Mysore-born Visvesaraya--whose birthday on September 15 is celebrated as Engineer's Day in India, Sri Lanka and Tanzania --was also an ardent technocrat whose work continues to touch sugarcane farmers in Maharashtra and Karnataka, picnickers in the Brindavan Gardens, and city dwellers across the country who enjoy a piped water supply.Even as India grapples with politically skewed biographies and pseudo science, the author talks toabout the need for nuance while researching historically important scientists and engineers such as VisvevarayaSix years ago, your first book 'The Birth of an Indian Profession' explored the history of engineers in India between 1900 and 1947. How did the role of engineers evolve during these interwar years?In those years, new types of engineers came to prominence, namely those working in large-scale industries. (Earlier the profession was dominated by engineers in public works, railways, and the military.) Not only that, there was an increasing presence of Indian engineers as opposed to expat British engineers. A good example of the new type of engineer would be PN Mathur, a metallurgist who worked for Ford in the US before joining the Tata Iron and Steel Company in the 1920s.Like most of us, I’d heard of Visvesvaraya while growing up. While researching my first book, I kept coming across nuggets on him, and realised he was an exceptional figure. I was intrigued by the question of what made him so influential and legendary. What was the historical context in which he worked? How did his engineering expertise and his views on economic development take shape and evolve? To try and understand some of these things, I decided to research his life and career.Visvesvaraya lived from 1861 to 1962, a period that saw so many fundamental developments in the history of the Indian nation. Moreover, he was involved, directly or indirectly, with many of them: the popularisation of economic planning, the conception of constitutional autonomy within the British empire, the evolving status of the princely states, the emphasis on industrialisation and large dam projects. He worked with the most prominent Indian politicians of his time, but also with institution-builders, scientists, and engineers. He made technocracy fashionable, something that has reverberations down to the present day.I began by reading existing accounts of Visvesvaraya, which gave me a good sense of what was known about him and what had not been explored yet. I decided I wanted to rely on primary sources as far as possible. I went to various government and private archives in Mumbai, Delhi, Bengaluru, and Mysuru. I found records related to his time in the Bombay PWD, studied his correspondence with politicians and others, and combed through his own extensive collection of government reports and newspaper cuttings. I also looked at records related to his close associates such as Walchand Hirachand. Digitised databases of official reports and newspapers from his time were immensely helpful. The biggest challenge was the subject’s reticence – he was a private person who didn’t leave behind too many personal letters or diaries, and it was difficult initially to probe beyond the public persona. But by immersing myself in the available sources, I hope I have been able to illuminate his personality and his thought process.You’re right, he’s ubiquitous in Karnataka. But while he enjoys name recall in other parts of the country, I don’t think his significance on the national stage is adequately appreciated. Yes, he had a huge influence on princely Mysore, but his canvas was much wider. He advised on dams and waterworks across undivided India and even in Aden. He worked closely with national politicians like MM Malaviya and MR Jayakar. He played a key role in bringing the concept of economic planning to the fore. He influenced technical education policy.Visvesvaraya spent close to 25 years in Poona and other parts of Bombay Presidency as a PWD engineer. During this time he absorbed the colonial philosophy of irrigation, but also made his own extensions based on his experiences, including that of famine in the Deccan. He got to know industrialists and intellectuals interested in national politics, especially MG Ranade and GK Gokhale. Later in life, he split his residence between Bangalore and Bombay city for many years. This meant he continued to be in close contact with developments in the industrial and commercial worlds, as well as with politicians on the national stage.The two shared a respectful relationship, and tried hard to find a meeting ground through their correspondence. But ultimately they were unable to agree on the question of large-scale industrialisation in particular, and of course their visions for India were quite different. I think Visvesvaraya’s views on the centrality of science and tech came partly from his education in colonial institutions, but mainly from his study tours to Japan, Europe, and America. Japan in particular was an important model for him.I drifted into engineering without thinking too deeply about my options. While I did alright in my studies, I found myself most excited by the courses I took outside of my main subject, and the general reading I was doing. After deep reflection, I realised I had a long-standing, if dormant, interest in history, and that I had questions about how we’d got to where we were in terms of engineering, IT, and related fields. This prompted me to switch fields. I think the time in graduate school abroad helped me understand my country a bit better by giving me some distance. Interacting with mentors and other scholars from around the world also helped broaden my perspective and look at Indian history as part of global developments.I’m not aware of the deeper reasons behind the cancellation/postponement—I think we’ll have to wait a year or two to understand its significance. But as far as historically unsupportable claims about science and tech in ancient India are concerned, they seem to indicate a deep insecurity. With the many strides India has made since Independence, isn’t it time to be more confident and look at our own past objectively?In the age of rampant misinformation, pseudo-science and questionable history textbooks, why is revisiting the professional lives of scientific and technical practitioners important?It’s important because there is a tendency to create icons, hollow out the complexity of their lives, and use them selectively to support present-day agendas. This points to the need for nuanced biographies in general. Especially when it comes to scientists and engineers, it’s always important to understand how their thinking evolved, how they were conditioned by the social and political context, and what assumptions they made. We need to look at primary sources in as much detail as possible, and study their lives with an open mind.Always difficult to answer these! My guess is that he would have been largely excited by the first three, to the extent that they could be applied to improve public health and material prosperity. Yet I think he would have been critical of several aspects of the present situation. He would find our cities disorderly, lament the continuing existence of poverty, and disapprove of the cultural chauvinism in much of today’s public discourse.
Article Summary: Mokshagundam Visvesvaraya was one of the most famous Indian engineers of the 20th century. Author Aparajith Ramnath's new biography 'Engineering a Nation' delves into the scientist's century-wide life and legacy. The author talks toabout the need for nuance while researching historically important scientists and engineers.
